image.altText: An animated concept design showing a football stadium, from above.

props.synopsis: Devonport City Council says a proposed $60 million multi-sport precinct will be a "game changer" for the city, despite some local opposition. Public consultation for the project closes at the end of the week.

title.children: 'Game changer' or wrong spot? Public consultation open for multi-sports centre and stadium in Devonport

image.altText: A flag with black on the top, red on the bottom and a yellow circle in the middle held up high at a gathering of people.

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian government was due to introduce a bill earlier this year to amend the legislation governing the return of Aboriginal land. Instead, it's shelved it â€” and that's received a mixed reaction.

title.children: Tasmanian government shelves plans to amend law governing return of Aboriginal land

image.altText: Man speaking in front of microphones to a group of people

props.synopsis: Tasmania's opposition and crossbench are poised to spring a no-confidence motion on deputy premier Michael Ferguson next week to see him removed from cabinet over the handling of the bungled Spirit of Tasmania ferries project.

title.children: 'A lot of butt covering going on': Tasmania's deputy premier responds as he faces talk of no-confidence motion

image.altText: An animation of a man lecturing a mother and son in a park.

props.synopsis: Claire thought that she'd escaped domestic violence after leaving her abusive partner, but she then struggled to find help with the violent meltdowns from her trauma-affected son.

title.children: 'That boy needs a beating': Claire was in shock at unsolicited advice, she wanted to say the problem was 'he's already had one'

image.altText: London plane trees in a park.

props.synopsis: Next to Hobart's iconic Salamanca Market there are more than a dozen London plane trees providing cover and shade. Stallholders say it's time for them to go due to allergy complaints.

title.children: These trees may look pretty â€” but stallholders at Hobart's Salamanca Market want them gone

image.altText: A whale washed up on a beach

props.synopsis: Five sperm whales found washed up on a remote Tasmanian Island have all died, with the beach to remain closed while samples are taken.

title.children: No survivors at sperm whale stranding on Flinders Island

image.altText: Two young boys in hoodies wade into the ocean and point at dark shapes beneath the surface.

props.synopsis: Weather conditions and shifting sands temporarily reveal an ancient "elder" forest on a Tasmanian beach, preserved from thousands of years ago.

title.children: Did you miss? ðŸ“£ 'Preserved' trees thousands of years old uncovered on beach after storm surge

image.altText: Special forces soldier

props.synopsis: Questions are being raised about how alleged war crimes by the Australian Defence Forces are investigated, following the response to the Brereton inquiry.

title.children: Why investigating the alleged war crimes of Australian soldiers is proving so difficult

image.altText: A rickshaw in Bangladesh is cycled through flood waters covering the frame with a passenger in tow.

props.synopsis: A study of scenarios where the world temporarily exceeds 1.5C of warming raises concerns for effects that may not be reversible for decades â€” or longer.

title.children: Temporarily overshooting 1.5C climate target more damaging than we thought: study

image.altText: Anthony Albanese wears a dark suit, smiles, and shakes hands with Li Qiang who is in a black suit

props.synopsis: It will be his fifth meeting with Li Qiang, and his second in only a few months.

title.children: Anthony Albanese will meet Chinese Premier Li Qiang on the sidelines of ASEAN summit

image.altText: A woman wearing a dark green hijab and blazer stands in a grass field, serious expression on her face

props.synopsis: Fatima Payman's new political party may not be troubling Labor, but it still has plenty of other headaches to worry about.

title.children: Fatima Payman's big reveal of her new political party has done little to trouble Labor

image.altText: A plume of grey smoke rises from blocks of city apartments at night-time, with lights everywhere

props.synopsis: Israeli air strikes in central and northern Gaza killed 12 people, local authorities said, including nine members of one family.

title.children: Hezbollah claims Israeli troops repelled from southern Lebanon, reports family of nine killed in Gaza air strike

image.altText: A red hammer in a circle on a green background on the side of a building.

props.synopsis: Bunnings is Australia's most trusted brand. But allegations the hardware chain has been abusing its market power have prompted a Senate inquiry, that is set to scrutinise the market power of many large format retailers.

title.children: Too big, too powerful? Why â€˜big boxâ€™ retail chains like Bunnings and Petstock are being scrutinised

image.altText: A sign reads 'BEAUMARIS PRIMARY SCHOOL' behind gum leaves.

props.synopsis: A survivor of "shocking" sexual abuse at a Melbourne primary school has received what his lawyer has called "the biggest publicly-known payment to an abuse survivor in Australia" in an extraordinary $8 million settlement with the Victorian Education Department.

title.children: Sexual abuse survivor to receive $8 million in record-breaking settlement

image.altText: A dark-haired woman wearing a black jacket staring directly at the camera

props.synopsis: The ACT Greens defend their vetting process after admitting to knowing about a candidate's blog post comparing September 11 mastermind Osama bin Laden to Jesus Christ.

title.children: 'Remembered as heroes': ACT Greens forced to defend candidate's blog post comparing Bin Laden to Jesus

image.altText: A man with grey hair and glasses raises his hand

props.synopsis: Timor-Leste's president Jose Ramos-Horta has sharply criticised exploitation in Australia's Pacific labour scheme, warning that unscrupulous employers are over-charging workers from his country for accommodation and transport.Â

title.children: Timor-Leste president slams exploitation in Australia's PALM scheme, cites excessive living costs

image.altText: Jason Clare, wearing a suit, stands against a wall.

props.synopsis: A Labor-led Senate inquiry has recommended that a ministerial power to set international student caps at a course level be removed from the governmentâ€™s proposed legislation.

title.children: Ministerial power to set course-level international student caps should be scrapped, Senate committee says

image.altText: Four people in camo trekking up a grassy area.

props.synopsis: Ember, Jayda, and Maverick disappeared with their father into New Zealand's mountain ranges in 2021 â€” they've just been seen together for the first time in years.

title.children: Tom Phillips took his children and vanished into New Zealand's mountains three years ago. They've just been spotted

image.altText: Three young women eating instant noodles with chopsticks.

props.synopsis: Munch on a packet of chips, slurp up a bowl of noodles or tuck into a salami sandwich, and there's a good chance you're also eating monosodium glutamate (MSG). So is it really as bad for us as we're led to believe?

title.children: MSG has been misunderstood for decades. Scientists are now correcting the record

image.altText: An illustration of a young person talking to a police officer

props.synopsis: In the midst of a spike in Victorian youth crime, researchers say young people with intellectual disabilities are going unsupported and overlooked in the criminal justice system.

title.children: 'I was just saying yes, yes, yes': Young people with intellectual disabilities over-represented in justice system

image.altText: A blue sign with white writing that reads Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2024.

props.synopsis: The academy said one of the discoveries being recognised fulfils "a 50-year-old dream of predicting protein structures from their amino acid sequences".

title.children: Scientists David Baker, Demis Hassabis and John Jumper win Nobel Prize in Chemistry for 'predicting protein structures'

image.altText: A dark-haired woman stands in a unit near a window that overlooks a road.

props.synopsis: A man broke into this woman's home and raped her after she returned from a jog. She's challenging courts and prisons to do justice differently in the hope of curbing re-offending and putting survivors at the centre of the story.

title.children: Kat was violently attacked by a stranger. After confronting him in jail she's helping other victims do the same

image.altText: Satellite image of Hurricane Milton on approach to US

props.synopsis: Hurricane Milton is set to make landfall on Florida's west coast as a powerful and extremely dangerous category five storm.

title.children: Millions in Florida warned homes could become coffins when Hurricane Milton hits

image.altText: A middle-aged woman in a purple jacket gestures with her hands as she speaks at a press conference.

props.synopsis: Retirement village residents and their families have backed calls for tougher regulation of the sector, with one saying contracts should carry a cigarette-style financial health warning and another saying the industry is a "black hole".

title.children: Daughter of former retirement village resident calls for 'financial health warning' on village contracts

image.altText: New Zealand flag in front of civic buildings

props.synopsis: As Australians await stronger signals that a rates reprieve is imminent here, across the Tasman, New Zealand's central bank has again taken the knife to its key interest rate.

title.children: New Zealand 'doubles down' on interest rates retreat with more aggressive cut

image.altText: Putin, wearing an ear piece, looks over to his shoulder to the blurred profile of Trump closer in frame

props.synopsis: A new book by a Washington Post reporter claims the Republican nominee trying to return to the White House has had ongoing contact with Vladimir Putin.

title.children: New book claims Trump posted COVID tests to Putin in 2020

image.altText: Ken McCallum

props.synopsis: MI5 director general Ken McCallum says Britain is experiencing a staggering rise in assassination attempts and other crimes by Russia and Iran.Â

title.children: Britain's intelligence agency says Russia is trying to create 'mayhem' in the UK

image.altText: Barricades at a bridge Korean writing on it.

props.synopsis: North Korea's military said it will "completely cut off roads and railways" linked to South Korea and "fortify the relevant areas of our side with strong defence structures."Â

title.children: North Korea to 'permanently' shut border with South Korea

image.altText: A dark-haired woman stands in a unit near a window that overlooks a road.

props.synopsis: A man broke into this woman's home and raped her after she returned from a jog. She's challenging courts and prisons to do justice differently in the hope of curbing re-offending and putting survivors at the centre of the story.

title.children: Kat was violently attacked by a stranger. After confronting him in jail she's helping other victims do the same

image.altText: Reece raises his arms as he crossed the Melbourne Marathon finish line, with the time 02:14:35 on a screen above him.

props.synopsis: Reece Edwards had enough saved for a house deposit when he was 20, but spent the money on other experiences instead. While some might see that as a "financial disaster", he has a different take.

title.children: The elite runner who is such a diligent saver, his 'guilty splurge' is a weekly banh mi

image.altText: Two Melbourne Rebels players after their Super Rugby Pacific loss to the Hurricanes.

props.synopsis: The Melbourne Rebels issue proceedings in the Federal Court against Rugby Australia after they were excluded from next year's Super Rugby Pacific competition.

title.children: 'An appalling lack of judgement': Axed Melbourne Rebels chasing $30 million in damages from Rugby Australia

image.altText: Jacob Hersant, dressed in a white shirt and blue suit, photographed in dappled sunlight outdoors.

props.synopsis: A magistrate says Melbourne man Jacob Hersant will be sentenced to jail after being found guilty of performing a Nazi salute last year. He's the first person found guilty of breaking a new Victorian law that bans the salute.

title.children: Melbourne man found guilty of performing Nazi salute to be jailed

image.altText: crisafulli and gerber listening to a constituent's question

props.synopsis: David Crisafulli has once again sidestepped questions about whether he would allow a conscience vote on a future KAP bill to repeal abortion laws â€” and why he voted against Labor's decriminalisation bill in 2018.

title.children: LNP leader refuses to say if his MPs will get conscience vote on abortion

image.altText: A street sign for Chinamans Lane

props.synopsis: A South Australian council has voted to keep the controversial name of a rural road in Penola. A descendant of one of the first Chinese people in the area says renaming Chinamans Lane would erase a part of local history.

title.children: Council votes unanimously against changing street's 'offensive' name

image.altText: Chief Maycon, an Indigenous Krenak leader (left), is fighting a court battle against BHP

props.synopsis: Nineteen people died and vast swathes of land and waterways were damaged when BHP and local mining company Vale's tailing dam collapsed in 2015. Now, First Nations and traditional Brazilian people are lobbying ahead of a major class action.

title.children: Is your god worth $70 billion? Indigenous Brazilians think so and want BHP to pay up
